Dear Ms. Berkobien:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 243-9743.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not
limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or
pushing a youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff 1 pushed Youth A to the ground during an altercation.
Investigation The Complainant was contacted on 04/22/2024 and had no
additional information to provide.
The Chief Administrator and Clinical Director were spoken to
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility on
03/13/2024. The Chief Administrator was aware of the incident
that had occurred involving Staff 1 and Youth A and confirmed
that Staff 1 had been put on administrative leave prior to this visit
to the facility. Video footage was viewed of the incident.
Youth A was interviewed during an unannounced, face-to-face
visit to the facility on 03/13/2024. Youth A recalled the incident in
question. He stated he was walking out of the unit one day when
he encountered Staff 1 in the doorway exiting the unit. Youth A
stated Staff 1 pushed him in his chest, and he fell backward to the
floor. He didn't recall Staff 1 saying anything to him at that time.
Youth A didn’t believe there were any other staff or youth around
when this occurred. He stated he stayed on the ground for quite a
while after this occurred but a staff member, he could not recall
who helped him up. He did not believe he was injured because of
this incident. Youth A recalled being upset prior to when this
occurred because his unit was supposed to go on an outing, but
they were then told they could not. He denied attempting to walk
off the unit because of being upset. Youth A stated he had never
had any incidents before with Staff 1.
Staff 2 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
03/20/2024. He stated he witnessed the incident in question in
full. Staff 2 recalled Youth A walking towards the exit doorway of
2

the unit, and at that time Staff 2 believed Youth A was attempting
to walk off the unit without permission. He did not recall Youth A
saying anything. Staff 2 stated Staff 1 then came to the same
doorway and pushed Youth A, causing Youth A to fall to the
ground. He specified Staff 1 pushed Youth A with one hand into
Youth A’s chest. Staff 2 commented that this physical contact felt
excessive compared to the behavior presented by Youth A. Staff
2 had never seen Staff 1 behave this way or react to a youth’s
behavior this way.
The Chief Administrator was interviewed over the phone on
04/18/2024. She confirmed Staff 1 was still on administrative
leave and she had not spoken with Staff 1 specifically about the
incident or since the time that he was put on leave because of the
pending investigations.
During a video conference call on 04/05/2024 DHHS Worker 1
stated her investigation would not produce any findings.
Staff 1 was interviewed over the phone on 04/22/2024. He was
able to recall the incident in question. Staff 1 stated he was
walking out of the unit when he moved through the doorway, and
when he turned around to close the door behind him, he realized
that Youth A was behind him and attempting to come out of the
unit as well. Youth A was not moving quickly and did not say
anything at that time. Staff 1 stated Youth A had his hand on the
door as Staff 1 attempted to close it. In response, Staff 1 stopped
closing the door and put his hand out to Youth A and made
contact with Youth A’s shoulder. Staff 1 stated this resulted in a
push and caused Youth A to fall to the ground. Staff 1 clarified
that he did not know that Youth A had fallen to the ground until he
returned to the unit 15 or 20 minutes later. Staff 1 stated his intent
was not to push Youth A but to remove him from the doorway and
prevent him from exiting the unit and having the door closed on
him. Staff 1 stated Youth A did not say anything during this
interaction, and Staff 1 did not say anything to Youth A either
because he then turned around and walked away.
Documents reviewed:
• The personnel file for Staff 1 was reviewed. He had no
formal discipline noted but did have several examples of
documented coaching regarding agency values,
consistency with staff and youth, paperwork, spatial
awareness and line of sight efforts, proper locking of doors
and personal cell phone use.
3

• An incident report dated 03/05/2024 was provided and
reviewed. This was authored by Supervisor 1, although he
wasn’t a witness to the event. This documentation noted
Staff 2 witnessed Youth A being pushed by Staff 1 as a
response to Youth A attempting to walk off the unit. The
same documentation contained narrative from Staff 1
stating Youth A had attempted to push past him to get to
the main hallway, and Staff 1 prevented this by protecting
his physical boundaries.
• Video footage was provided and viewed:
o One camera angle was located directly above the
doorway within the unit, and the end of the
hallway. Staff 1 was first seen standing near the
doorway and then exiting out of the unit. Youth A
walked toward the same doorway and arrived at it
about 15 seconds later. Staff 2 can be seen walking
behind Youth A. He then opened the door and
attempted to pass through the doorway. Youth A
then fell backward to the ground directly in front of
Staff 2. Staff 1 could not be seen at that point in
time.
o Two other camera angles of the incident were
viewed during the 03/13/2024 on-site visit. One
camera angle was in the space outside of the
unit. No parts of the incident itself could be viewed
because of a small alcove area located directly
outside of the unit doorway. A second camera angle
was viewed inside of the unit at the opposite end of
the hallway from the door where the incident
occurred. Because of the distance and other youth
and staff that were in the hallway more near this
camera angle there was no view of the incident
itself.
• Facility policy titled “Residential AWOL Protocol” was
provided and reviewed. This policy provided proper
instruction on staff’s responsibilities as a result of an AWOL
youth. It did not provide instruction on how to attempt to
prevent an AWOL, including physical contact.
Analysis Through interviews with youth and staff and documentation
reviewed there was evidence found that Staff 1 pushed Youth A
during the incident in question.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR #2024C0001164SI dated 04/04/24, CAP pending.
4

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
